title: Thinking like a gardener, slime mold, the adjacent possible: Product advice from Alex Komoroske
themes: AI and LLMs impact on product development
The adjacent possible and incremental progress
Taste and differentiation in the AI era
key_insights: LLMs are 'magical duct tape' that makes writing software cheaper but running it more expensive, fundamentally changing cost structures
Think like a gardener not a builder - plant seeds that can grow on their own rather than trying to control every outcome
Organizational kayfabe (things everyone knows are fake but acts like they're real) emerges naturally and compounds up organizational layers
The adjacent possible is smaller than we think - focus on actions within arm's reach that definitely work, then iterate
Taste becomes the key differentiator when AI can produce most content - stand out by having a perspective different from what an LLM would generate
Create 'strategy salons' or nerd clubs with 'yes, and' energy to generate emergent insights in low-stakes environments
Always rules are better than sometimes rules for self-control and building sustainable habits
Do things that give you energy AND that you're proud of - this combination creates sustainable high performance

guest_background.current_role: Startup founder reimagining the web for the AI era

topics_discussed: How LLMs will change product development economics
The gardening vs building mindset for product strategy
Organizational kayfabe and how it emerges in companies
The slime mold model of organizational structure
Strategy salons and building internal communities
The adjacent possible framework for strategic planning
Bits and Bobs reflection practice and note-taking systems
WebSim as an example of AI-native products
The importance of taste in the AI era
The Compendium tool for knowledge management
The role of aggregators vs open ecosystems
memorable_quotes: LLMs are magical duct tape. They're formed principally by the distilled intuition of all of society into a thing that operates between a cost structure between human and plain old computing.
So much of the way that we tackle problems and build products is this builder mindset... What I look for instead are things that can be gardened, things that can grow on their own.
A community with zero people speaking is dead and a community with one person speaking doesn't yet realize it's dead.
recommended_for: Product managers transitioning to AI-first thinking
Senior leaders dealing with organizational complexity
Strategy professionals interested in systems thinking
Founders building in the AI era
Anyone interested in emergence-based approaches to innovation
summary: Alex Komoroske shares his unique systems-thinking approach to product strategy, explaining how AI will fundamentally change product development and why leaders should adopt a 'gardening' mindset focused on emergence rather than top-down control. The conversation covers organizational dynamics, strategic frameworks, and practical tactics for navigating complexity in the AI era.
